Darling Father . [ I shall now make a habit of sending any letters by
aerial mail. You will get them once a fortnight, which is "hardly
any different from ordinary" (I wonder what has become of Susan
Lushington ?) + you will get them in 10 days, + later, when the air
service is properly co-ordinated with the steamers, in a week.
For your part if you choose you can communicate with Mr
RW Bullard at the Middle Eastern
Dept Department
. Colonial office, + ask him
whether you can send your letters by air mail through him, as I
send mine to you. This is all, as yet, by favour + is therefore
not to be vaunted; presently we hope a civil post will be
regularly established. One thing more: Mr Bullard bears the
charge of stamping my letters but if you would send me
some English stamps that would be avoided. Tell me what
my letters to you generally weigh + how I should stamp
them - I'm not very certain of post-war rates. I
shall only send by air mail my letters to you or to my
brothers + sisters. The general public is to be left unacquainted
with the fact of there being a privileged air mail. But
won't it be splendid when we can get each other's answers
in a fortnight! ] even now we can get them in 3 weeks.
We've had a hot week -
temp. temperature
up again to 108°- but suddenly
it dropped yesterday to 92° + today for the first time
for 5 months I'm sitting in my little sitting room with
doors + windows open + no fan. It was so heavenly
this morning when I went out riding at 6 (it being Sunday)
that I rode right out across the desert to Fahamah ,
close on 2 hours away, + breakfasted with my friend
Faiq Beg . We sat in his garden, full of roses just
breaking into their second flower, while I eat hard
boiled eggs, native bread, + butter like cream, +
Faiq Beg talked. His face, which is the colour of a rosy
I'm dreadfully sorry to trouble you with an immense packet of papers from Mr Curmi whom
you saw here. He entreated me to send them!

apple + much the same shape - if you can imagine a rosy
apple with a fez on top - grew quite perturbed while he
related to me the difficulties of cultivators nowadays - the
labourers all gone off to better paid jobs in town, or
taking up land of their own on the new canals; they
think they do you a service in working for ten times
their former hire + even so, yallah , you're lucky if they
come an hour after dawn, don't knock off more than 4
hours at noon, nor leave earlier than an hour before
sunset. Poor Faiq Beg ! it's progress, of course; the country
is getting richer + the inhabitants expect more; but it's
very awkward for the old society when progress steps in
to dislocate it. And in the end it won't produce anything
better than Faiq Beg; straight out of Arcady he steps with
his rosy apple face, his personal rectitude + his industrious
days among his palms + orange trees + barley fields. But
in fact he is doing just the same thing as the labourers
whose ambition he deplores. He has sent his eldest son
to Beirut to study medicine at the American college,
after which he is to go for 4 years to America for his
medical degree. The father is as proud of him as he can
be - the boy's photograph lay before us as I eat my
hard boiled eggs - but "Khatun, the expense!" he sighs;
"for the first time in my life, wallahi , I'm in debt. For
the first time." I can well believe it. He himself lives on
the produce of his land: a bowl of curds, a clot of bread,
flavoured with dates, tomatoes, oranges to season.
Let me see what's been happening this week - I dined with the
King one night. They've an inconvenient habit of telephoning to you in
the morning + asking you to dinner that night. It happened that
I had invited two ministers, however I think it's best to treat
Faisal's invitations as commands so I hastily put them off
to next day. It proved very agreeable. No one was there but

explained who the people were + all about them. Then
Mr Garbett + I drafted an invitation form which I am
having printed + it looks as though I shall run the Court till it
gets on its feet. Curious, isn't it.
I sometimes think how curious it all is, yes, whether it's Faiq Beg
or King Faisal . People whose up bringing + associations + traditions
are all so entirely different, yet when one is with them one doesn't
notice the difference, nor do they. Think of Faisal, brought up at
Mecca in a palace full of eunuchs, educated at Constantinople ,
Commander in Chief, King, exile, then King again; or Faiq
tending his palms + vines, + jogging into Baghdad to seek out the
best market for his dates - + both of them run out to greet me
with outstretched hands + then sit down to tell me in their several
fashions what they make of life, as if I were a sister. And I
feel like a sister, that's the oddest part.
Next night I had my ministerial dinner, Haji Ahmad Ramzi
(Interior) + Naji Suwaidi (Justice), with the editor of the
most reputable local paper, Razzuq Daud , Mr Drower (acting
advisor to Justice) +
Capt Captain
Cooke of
Auqaf Ministry relating to endowments.
. It was very
pleasant. Haji Ramzi grew quite chatty - I like the old
thing very much.
Shaikh Honorific title meaning 'Elder', used for leaders of tribes and royal family members.
'Abdullah
came to tea that day + he
cemented an incipient friendship. He is pure gold, with the
acute Arab mentality added, like a sharply flashing diamond
catching the light which the metal misses.
We have had a small fandango in the Arab Army. For weeks past,
months indeed, we have known of insubordination among some
of the officers, partly Turkish propaganda + partly pure Arab
indiscipline, jealousy of Ja'far + Nuri mainly. With many
misgivings, Ja'far has dealt it a knock out blow by arresting
the ringleaders. The effect has been excellent. People
have suddenly realized that the Arab Army is something
tangible, that intrigue against Arab Ministers is high treason.
+ will be dealt with as such, that Faisal + Ja'far + we
behind them will stand no nonsense.
Another, very encouraging circumstance is the collapse of the

2 Rustam Haidar , Shaikh 'Abdullah (a darling old Hijazi whose father
+ grandfather have been in the service of Faisal 's family) + an
ADC aide-de-camp
. After
dinner the King + I sat for long on the balcony overlooking the river. A late
moon rose behind us + shone softly on the water while the
quffahs Type of coracle round boat used on the Tigris and Euphrates rivers.
loaded with melons floated down, each with its twinkling yellow
light. And Faisal unburdened his heart. It arose out of my urging
him to bring out his wife + children. He said he felt so uncertain
of the future, the country was largely pro-Turk + he didn't
know whether the British Government would not insist on terms
in the future treaty which he felt he could not accept. On the
last head I answered that it was absolutely necessary for us
to come to agreement with him or acknowledge complete failure;
if he went we must go too - we had no alternative - +
I saw no reason for anxiety of any kind. As to the first
said that we might be thankful for his very winning personality
+ why didn't he use it more? Yes, he said eagerly, he wanted
to come more into touch - should he not have little dinner
parties? + whom should he ask? I said I would draw him
up skeleton lists of dinner parties, English + Arab - he
mustn't mind if they were rather boring, the notables here
mostly are boring but the more you knew them + were on
familiar terms with them the better you liked them. He
burst out with his charmingly impetuous enthusiasm
" Wallahi ! you're the mistress of the house - ask whom
you think best". And then he went on to say that except
Mr Cornwallis + Col. Joyce + me he didn't know the British officers
+ didn't feel certain that they would give him the
sort of affectionately solicitous service he had had from
us in Syria . I said of course they would - he had
only to make friends with them + treat them as he
did Mr Cornwallis + me, + we parted full of plans.
Next morning I drew up lists +

Turkish attack in the north. An officer + some 60 Turkish soldiers
occupied Rawandaz (which we were not holding) roused the
insurgent elements among the Kurdish tribes + proceeded to
harry Batas + Rania . We have driven them out of the two
latter with aeroplanes, Levies + tribal forces + the really
satisfactory thing has been the efficiency of half trained or
wholly untrained native forces with aeroplane co-operation.
Aircraft bomb the way clear + the native forces walk
in after like clockwork. It is of very good omen for the Arab
army when it is left with little but aeroplane help from us,
as it soon will be.
You know that Armitage Smith has definitely been turned
out of Persia ? His second in command, a Mr Balfour , has
come here on his way home -
A.S. Armitage Smith
goes back by Bakhtiari +
Bushire . He is very interesting about Persia, Mr Balfour. He
thinks it is bound to get worse before it gets any better. There
appear to be two alternatives. The country may split up
into its component parts, a process which has begun
already for the provinces of Azarbaijan + Gilan have
declared themselves independent of the central
Govt Government
. Or
the Bolshevists may come in - there is a concentration
of some 100,000
Bolshe. Bolshevist
forces in the Caucasus , + the
Minister in Tehran , Rothstein , appears to be playing for a
break with the Persian
Govt Government
. In the first case Persia will
become chaotically
negligible negligable
; in the second Bolshevism,
by snuffing out another Moslem state will become thoroughly
discredited in the Moslem world. I don't therefore think that
either alternative can harm us here, + as for what
happens to Persia, I don't much care. We can do nothing more.
I must now break off to relate to you a tale of Mrs Rosita
Forbes . The wife of one of our doctors here going home on leave
observes a very elaborately clad lady get on the ship at Port
Said + take a long + intimate farewell with a party

in a fez - no doubt Hasanain . After he leaves the lady looks
so solitary that Mrs Sinderson strolls up, sits down by her
+ ventures a remark on the weather. Her
interlocutor intercolutor
rejoins
with "I suppose you know who I am?" "Well" says Mrs
Sinderson innocently "I know your name is Forbes - I saw
it on your hat box." Tableau! Really I think she must
be mad. She spoke to no one on the voyage but at night
when the passengers wanted to give concerts, she sat at
the middle table in the music room completely surrounded by
books, foolscap +
M.S. manuscript
, at which she never ceased to write
busily. What a woman!

September
27 . Sir Percy , who is a very keen sportsman, has got two hawks
which are being trained. Every morning there is a hawk party in the
office. Our hawks invite their friends + when I come in of a
morning I find two or three falconers, each with a couple of hawks
on his wrist waiting for Sir Percy to appear.
One of my daily jobs is to read + summarize the local papers.
I have as assistant a capital little Soudanese, black as your hat,
+ merry as a cricket. The more work you give him the merrier
he grows. His Arabic is excellent + his English far from bad
but very colloquial. His comments on the newspaper tosh
are a perpetual joy. Yesterday there was a literary piece
by one of our local poets.
Makki . Oh Lord! this fellow! This is a silly fellow. He
talks to the moon
